div1.p: Ireland requests that Kean inform Valery Havard of yellow fever cases in Havana. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 2, 1906
div1.opener:
m
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
Nov. 2, 1906
Major J. R. Kean,
Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Departamento de Sanidad,
Maestranza, Havana, Cuba.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
The Chief has just asked me to
write and request that you will telephone to
Colonel Havard every day the number of new
cases of yellow fever you have. I am going to
write to Colonel Havard in a few minutes and
ask him to cable this information to the of-
fice. The Chief thinks it would be of great
interest to us to have this information and
suggests this way of getting it.

Everything is going on in the usual way
here. Mrs. Young and Miss Dollie returned
to New York City this morning.

Lewis is before a board consisting of
Borden, Mason and Lynch. His lack of infor-
mation is simply pathetic.
